abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews summer white wines; photo (M)

block.p: To imagine how the critic Harold Bloom, a famously omnivorous reader, might feel in Barnes & Noble, stroll into such Manhattan shops as Astor or Chelsea Wine Vault: So many wines, so little time. Even devotees of heavy fiction need light aperitif ''reads,'' like these summer whites.

Burgundy The '98 Domaine de Champ Brule, a lovely, dry, fairly full-bodied Macon-Villages, $13.50, and the stylish, elegant '98 Pouilly-Fuisse $19, at Slope Cellars, 436 Seventh Avenue (15th Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn. (Both are Vincent Selections.)

Burgundy The '98 Domaine de Champ Brule, a lovely, dry, fairly full-bodied Macon-Villages, $13.50, and the stylish, elegant '98 Pouilly-Fuisse $19, at Slope Cellars, 436 Seventh Avenue (15th Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn. (Both are Vincent Selections.)

Loire Domaine Mardon '98 Quincy, vieilles vignes (old vines): This brisk wine, from vines dating back 80 years, delivers a tantalizing citric-herbal bouquet and splendid herbal finish. Let it linger on your palate. Chelsea Wine Vault, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), Manhattan, asks $14. (Distributed by Jeroboam Wines, owned by Daniel Johnnes, Montrachet's wine director.)

Spain Osborne Coquinero fino amontillado, an unusual sherry -- an aged fino -- of bracing dryness, with hints of almond. This pale, understated entry-level aperitif, which doubles your appetite, is $12 at 67 Wine, 179 Columbus Avenue (68th Street), Manhattan.

Fino stales quickly. Insist on a recent consignment, keep the wine iced, finish in 10 days. Think serrano ham or prosciutto, olives, nuts and Manchego cheese. The convivial English critic Hugh Johnson hits the bull's-eye: a glass of fino before or after gazpacho.

Chile The '98 Laura Hartwig chardonnay, a pretty, appley, to-the-point refresher from Santa Laura, a small producer that has attracted favorable notices: $13 at Brite-Buy, 11 Avenue of the Americas (Walker Street), Manhattan. (From Jeroboam.)
